lines.text: [first lines]

[narrating]
I was sore at myself for coming all the way out to Pasadena on a day like that just to see about a case. And how I hate summer winds - they come in suddenly off the Mojave Desert and you can taste sand for a week. I knew it was the voice of the girl on the phone that had got me and I was reminding myself how often your ears play a dirty trick on your eyes - but this time there was no let down...
Well, just having you here makes me sure everything's going to be all right.
You have even more confidence in my ability than I have. Where did you hear about me?
Oh, ah, I didn't. I just picked your name out of the phone book.
If I take the case, will you be around?
That depends on you, Mr. Marlowe. You look like a man with initiative.

You're Marlowe, aren't you? I've just seen my mother. I'm afraid we've put you to some slight trouble for nothing. She's decided she's not going to employ you or anyone for that matter. How much do I owe you?
Nothing, Mr. Murdock.

[to Marlowe]
Mrs. Murdock will see you now.
Thanks.
[to Leslie]
You must have forgotten to tell your mother.
What's been taken?
A coin. A rare gold coin called the Brasher Doubloon.
The what?
The Brasher Doubloon. It's a collector's item worth at least 10,000 dollars, probably more. It's a mint specimen - there's only two of them in the country.
Just a minute, Merle. You'd better write a check out for Mr. Marlowe. What do you charge for your services?
Well, if I take the case, 25 dollars a day, plus expenses.
I see. And how much of a retainer do you expect?
A hundred dollars will hold me.
I should hope it would!
[handing a check to Marlowe]
There you are and I hope you're worth it. To tell you the truth, I was expecting an older man - more intelligent looking.
I'm wearing a disguise.
always deposit retainer before client changes mind.

[narrating]
The Florence Apartments was a rooming house on Bunker Hill which used to be the choice place to live in Los Angeles. Nowadays, people lived there because they haven't any choice.

[narrating]
How I hate to find a stiff. A private detective has to work within an area roughly bounded by the law. Murder squeezes that area down to where you either can't operate or you have to take chances 25 dollars aren't worth.
You know somethin', Marlowe? You're smart - but don't try to be too smart.
All right - I'll try to be just smart enough.

[to Merle]
Now I know this is going to sound kind of radical, but did it ever occur to you that it might make things easier if you told the truth occasionally?

[discussing the Brasher Doubloon]
You can call the police and tell them I've got it and won't give it back to you... No police, eh? You know, I don't blame you. I don't like 'em either right now, 'cause they think I know more about those murders then I've told them. Is that your reason, too, Mrs. Murdock? And yours, Miss Davis?
Would you like me to tell you why I came here?
Yeah, then I can concentrate on the real reason.
How do you figure on getting me to give you the doubloon tonight?
By telling you the truth and then asking you for it.
You better go easy on that whiskey, Miss Davis. That sounded like a direct answer to a direct question.

[pointing a gun at Marlowe]
I'm afraid I'll have to ask you to take off your clothes.

[amused]
Miss Davis!
[last lines]

[referring to the kissing 'lessons' he's been giving Merle]
I've got a feeling you're going to graduate with honors.
